> [{quoted}](name=Catastrop,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=z5zuIPef,comment-id=00000002,timestamp=2016-11-07T22:56:07.529+0000)
>
> Those bars based on how easy the champion is to pick up and play. Not a representation of difficulty to master.

Yep, that's the primary intent here. That value's there more as a 'what will my initial experience be like/how long should I expect to have to play to be ok at this champ' measurement than anything else. It's not reflective of skill ceiling, but skill floor, hence Ashe, Trist, Ez and Caitlyn as 1 bar champs. A lot of that reflects their relative safety, with good disengage and/or utility that's valuable even if behind.

Out of curiosity, why is {{champion:222}} a 2 bar if she's one of the champions available to brand new players? Wouldn't it make sense to either move her to the 1 bar category or to replace her in the new player rotation with a 1 bar champ?

From memory Jinx was a borderline case we eventually put as a 2 because her ability to get out of a fight had more room for error. Certainly a debatable one though. 

In terms of the new player rotation, easy to play champs isn't exactly our goal for champs there. What we want are champs that new players will have a good time with. That's correlated with easier to play, but not identical to it. A significant part of the difference there is that the new player rotation champs, when used by genuinely new players, are mainly being used in Co-Op versus AI as players play their first half a dozen or so games.
Best to set Kog'Maw at 3 bars since even with 400+ ranked games I can only win 45% of my games after patch 6.21.

To be honest, vayne is alot more easy to pick up than tristana, same with Jinx.
Tristana actually is one of the hardest Marksmen with her E +the W reset mechanics. 
She's by no means the rightclick bot she was a couple of seasons ago.

I would think Ez is a bit harder than the others because you have to learn "oh hey, Essence Flux guzzles my mana bar without actually doing anything."

Not saying he's hard to learn. Just a bit harder than Trist or Cait.

There's more to difficulty than mechanics, and this list clearly doesn't take into account anything but skill floor, aka, how difficult this champion is to pick up and play.

If it took into account skill cap, the top tier would consist of Draven and Azir. Maybe Kalista or Vayne.

Oh, Ezreal would also be far higher. Ezreal being "forgiving" doesn't make him "easy", at least in the highest levels of play.

You say the only consequence is his DPS lacking?

Oh... so the only consequence is being incapable of properly doing his job as an ADC. 

Have you ever wondered why Ezreal, even when he is considered one of the best ADCs, almost always hovers around a fairly low, 49-50% win rate?

There is a world of difference in effectiveness between a noob Ezreal and one who has mastered the champion.

Teemo's skill floor is also pretty low, since it is not hard to take Teemo to lane and beat people up effectively, but to effectively use his kit to pressure the map and make use of his weirdly versatile build options effectively require more competence than just taking him to lane and beating the shit out of Tryndamere.

Kindred is ranked as difficult because she is:

A. a squishy ADC jungler who has trouble clearing safely for new players, as opposed to someone like Xin Zhao or Warwick who remain at near full health for their entire clear.

B. Reliant on a strong early game to scale into late game, which means she is very unforgiving while behind.

C. Has to scout out her targets much more thoughtfully than most other junglers, since as said before she has to win early to scale into late.

Do I have any problems playing Kindred? Not really no, but then I can pick up almost any champion in the game and do reasonably well (I am awful at Lee Sin though, truly dog shit).

But see, these rankings are for less experienced players.

It's why Rumble has such a high difficulty rating on the current client, despite being shit baby easy to play. He has to manage a very unique resource to make the most of his kit, and while a champion like Riven has a much higher skill ceiling, that aspect makes him less forgiving for a punk ass noob.

I honestly don't get why people base difficulty off of "skillshots or no skillshots" "flashy or not flashy"

The more important thing is **how forgiving of mistakes they are**
Ashe has no inherent escape/mobility. She has to ult to get out of a fight
Ezreal is super slippery and you have a lot of leeway for mistakes/misplays. He also doesn't need to position very well.

There's a reason why people say Zed, Yasuo, and Riven don't take as much skill as people say they do. They can make tons of mistakes and get away with it, while any other champion would be dead for doing so.

**INCORRECT!**

The most important thing is **how hard is it to achieve acceptable impact on them.**
If you endlessly run and get nothing done, you aren't learning the champion at all and won't be winning. You aren't PLAYING the champion, just running constantly. You can't win from non-stop running (unless you are Singed or maybe Tryndamere). It is harder to get minimum contribution as Ezreal then say Caitlyn when you are first learning them. Assuming you know what each ability does, it's easier to play Caitlyn since majority of her damage cannot be dodged (only Q and R can be actively dodged, W is more avoided) and she has a long basic attack range.
Ezreal CAN'T win by using basic attacks. He has to non-stop land Qs and Rs to win while also choosing to use E offensively or not. His W is the only super simple part of his kit, and even it provides some choices although those choices are mainly linked to his E. Basically, sure, you can EEEEEEE away as Ezreal, but you can't win by doing that against any team that isn't terrible.

This is called the DPS Burden. It's less common in LoL since most DPS is targeted that carries games, but it becomes much bigger for people with skill shots. If you can't land the skill shots as them, you might as well just be an empowered minion that can flee. It's why Thresh, Bard, and Nidalee are so hard to play. If you can't land the abilities on them that aren't targeted or instant, you basically provide NOTHING for your team but some weak utility (and with Bard you can potentially even KILL allies).

Zed I have never heard called hard to play, but hard to master, which is 100% true. Riven is neither super hard or super easy to play. She is somewhere in between since you DO need limited knowledge of animation canceling to play her to an equal effect to others. Yasuo  is weird since he is only really hard to play for the first couple games, but then his learning curve heavily curves to become easier. He DOES have some depth, but he is no Azir.
